scenarioObject.Prompt: Patient is a 68 year old male presenting with fever and arthralgia.
scenarioObject.Suspected: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Temporal Arteritis.

Present Illness History.Output: The patient was well until 4 weeks prior to admission when he developed arthralgia in his wrists and shoulders. He also developed fatigue. He began taking ibuprofen, but developed abdominal pain. OGD (Oesophagogastroduodenoscopy) showed several gastric ulcers. One week prior to admission, the arthralgia again worsened, and he developed fever and headache.

Past Medical History.Output: No prior illnesses or hospitalizations.

Medication.Output: Ranitidine.

Social History.Output: He is divorced, and lives alone. He denied tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drug use.

Auscultate Lungs.Output: The lungs are clear.

Auscultate the Heart.Output: Normal heart sounds, no gallop, and no murmurs.

Assess Eyes.Output: The conjunctivae were pale. The sclerae were anicteric. The pupils were equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation. The fundi were normal.

Abdomen Examination.Output: The abdomen was soft, without tenderness. There was no hepatosplenomegaly or masses.

Rectal Examination.Output: Rectal examination was normal; the stool was negative for occult blood.

NeckThroat Examination.Output: The oropharynx was normal. The neck was supple. There was no lymphadenopathy or thyromegaly.

Assess Head.Output: Evidence of bitemporal wasting. Scalp feels tender.

Neurologic Exam Record.Output: The neurological exam including mental status, cranial nerves, strength and sensation was normal.

Assess Extremities.Output: The extremities showed no joint swelling; there was pain in the shoulders on abduction to 90 degrees. There was no cyanosis, clubbing, or oedema.

Urine Dipstick.Output: No protein or blood; microscopic examination normal.

ECG.Output: Sinus tachycardia, but was otherwise normal.

Venous Blood Gas.Output: pH: 7.34 (Normal: 7.33 to 7.44), PCO2: 5.6 (Normal: 5 to 6.4kPa), PO2: 6.0  (Normal: > 5.3 kPa), HCO3: 24 (Normal: 22 to 28 mmolL), Base Excess: 1 (Normal: 2), Saturation: 73 (Normal: 72 to 75%), Lactate: 1.6 (Normal: 0.5 to 2.2  mmolL)

UREA and Electrolytes.Output: Sodium: 139 (Normal: 135 to 145 mmolL), Potassium: 4.4 (Normal: 3.5 to 5.0 mmolL), Urea: 5.1 (Normal: 2.5 to 6.7 mmolL), Creatinine: 88 (Normal: 70 to 150 micromolL), eGFR: >90 (Normal: >90mlmin1.73m2)

Clotting Test.Output: Prothrombin Time: 11 (Normal: 10 to 14 seconds), APTT: 30 (Normal: 22 to 36 seconds), Fibrinogen: 2.9 (Normal: 1.5 to 4.5 gL)

FBC.Output: Hb: 93 (Normal: 130 to 180 gL), Hct: 0.28 (Normal: 0.40 to 0.54 LL), MCV: 73.9 (Normal: 80 to 100 fl), WBC: 9.2 (Normal: 3.6 to 11.0 x 109L), Neut: 7.6 (Normal: 1.8 to 7.5  x 109L), Lymph's: 1.4 (Normal: 1.0 to 4.0  x 109L), Platelet Count: 490 (Normal: 140 to 400 x 109L)

scenarioObject.Prompt: Patient is a 60 year old male presented with 2 day history of bloody diarrhoea.
scenarioObject.Suspected: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Ulcerative Colitis.

Present Illness History.Output: The patient has a history of hypertension, osteoarthritis and diverticulitis. He had been doing well until about three weeks prior to admission, when he developed loose, watery bowel movements and an associated crampy left lower quadrant abdominal pain. The bowel movements occurred about 45 times per day. Prior to admission, he noted blood in his bowel movements, as well as fevers to 39 degrees celsius, chills and sweats. He did note fatigue and a decrease in weight of 14 pounds relative to his baseline.

Past Medical History.Output: Significant for diverticulitis: diagnosed first in 1999 after a presentation with fresh blood in stool, relatively asymptomatic recently, hypertension, osteoarthritis in his hands, and recurrent epistaxis.

Medication.Output: Diltiazem and hydrochlorothiazide, neither started recently.

Social History.Output: Unremarkable.

Auscultate Lungs.Output: Lungs were clear to auscultation.

Auscultate the Heart.Output: His cardiac rhythm was regular and no extra heart sounds or murmurs were appreciated.

Assess Eyes.Output: Conjunctivae were pale. The pupils were equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation.

Abdomen Examination.Output: His abdominal examination revealed bowel sounds and mild tenderness to palpation over the left lower quadrant without rebound or guarding. No masses or organomegaly were present.

Rectal Examination.Output: Rectal examination revealed no palpable masses or obvious haemorrhoids. The stool was grossly bloody.

NeckThroat Examination.Output: The neck and oropharynx were normal.

Assess Head.Output: Normal

Neurologic Exam Record.Output: Neurological examination was normal.

Assess Extremities.Output: Nails were pale. Distal and radial pulses were equal.

Urine Dipstick.Output: Trace leukocytes in dipstick and occasional WBC on microscopic examination.

ECG.Output: Sinus tachycardia, but was otherwise normal.

scenarioObject.Prompt: Patient is a 62 year old male admitted for fevers and generalised weakness.
scenarioObject.Suspected: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Miliary TB.

Present Illness History.Output: Ten years prior to admission, the patient developed pancytopenia. Evaluation included a bone marrow biopsy which revealed refractory anaemia. The patient's myelodysplastic syndrome remained indolent throughout the subsequent 10 years. Three months prior to admission the patient developed daily fevers and fatigue. One month prior to admission the patient presented to an outside hospital for diagnostic evaluation. Examination revealed a high temperature, a right inguinal hernia, and a right axillary mass (3 cm in diameter, no fluctuance, slightly tender).

Past Medical History.Output: Myelodysplastic syndrome, Type II Diabetes (10 years, dietcontrolled), hypertension (10 years).

Medication.Output: GCSF (Granulocyte Colony Stimulating Factor), verapamil, Fybogel

Social History.Output: Regular (daily) smoker, has not travelled recently.

Assess Eyes.Output: The pupils were equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation.

Abdomen Examination.Output: Abdomen was distended, with shifting dullness, a right inguinal hernia (reducible), and normal bowel sounds.

Rectal Examination.Output: Rectal exam was unremarkable.

NeckThroat Examination.Output: Within normal limits

scenarioObject.Prompt: Patient is a 58 year old female presented with shortness of breath.
scenarioObject.Suspected: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Aortic Dissection.

Present Illness History.Output: The patient had a history of hypertension and had had three weeks of intermittent left sided chest pain. The pain radiated to the back. There was no change with exertion. Pains lasted for approximately one minute. She also complained of increasing shortness of breath over the previous month. She became dyspneic performing minimum household chores. She had an occasional nonproductive cough. She had been seen by a GP prior to admission, found to be hypertensive and started on treatment. She complained of night sweats and fever over the previous week but had no weight loss.

Past Medical History.Output: She had previous trauma to the right eye resulting in blindness. She had a total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral oophorectomy in the 1990's.

Medication.Output: Her medications on admission included verapamil 180 mg once per day, ramipril 5 mg once per day, and furosemide 20 mg once per day

Social History.Output: She smoked for ten years, but stopped twenty years ago. She drinks one bottle of beer every six months. She works in the home and lives with her husband.

Auscultate the Heart.Output: The first and second heart sounds were normal. There was an S4 and a IIVI systolic ejection murmur.

Assess Eyes.Output: Her pupils were equally round and reactive to light. The right cornea was opacified.

Abdomen Examination.Output: The abdomen was soft and nontender with no masses, or organomegaly.

Rectal Examination.Output: NAD and faecal occult blood was negative.

NeckThroat Examination.Output: There was no thyromegaly or adenopathy. Jugular venous pulsations were visible at 8 cm.

Assess Head.Output: Normal.

The patient complained of fever, feelings of faintness and occasional chills.

Medication.Output: None

Rectal Examination.Output: Rectal examination was normal

trialInfoSet.Prompt: Patient is a 62 year old male admitted for fevers and generalised weakness.
trialInfoSet.Suspected: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Miliary TB.

Present Illness History.Output: Ten years prior to admission, the patient developed pancytopenia. Evaluation included a bone marrow biopsy which revealed refractory anaemia. The patient's myelodysplastic syndrome remained indolent throughout the subsequent 10 years. Three months prior to admission the patient developed daily fevers and fatigue. One month prior to admission the patient presented to an outside hospital for diagnostic evaluation. Examination revealed a high temperature, a right inguinal hernia, and a right axillary mass (3 cm in diameter, no fluctuance, slightly tender).

Past Medical History.Output: Myelodysplastic syndrome, Type II Diabetes (10 years, dietcontrolled), hypertension (10 years).

Medication.Output: GCSF (Granulocyte Colony Stimulating Factor), verapamil, Fybogel

Social History.Output: Regular (daily) smoker, has not travelled recently.

Assess Eyes.Output: The pupils were equal, round, and reactive to light and accommodation.

Abdomen Examination.Output: Abdomen was distended, with shifting dullness, a right inguinal hernia (reducible), and normal bowel sounds.

Rectal Examination.Output: Rectal exam was unremarkable.

NeckThroat Examination.Output: Within normal limits

Assess Head.Output: No irregularities.

Neurologic Exam Record.Output: Within normal limits.

Assess Extremities.Output: Mild pedal oedema, multiple ecchymoses of various sizes.

Urine Dipstick.Output: Specific gravity 1.020 (normal: 1.005 to 1.025), 3 to 5 RBC (normal: <3 RBC) 0 to 3 WBC, no casts.

ECG.Output: No irregularities

trials.presentation: Patient is a 58 year old female presented with shortness of breath.
trials.prompt: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Aortic Dissection.

trialInfoSet.Prompt: Patient is a 58 year old female presented with shortness of breath.
trialInfoSet.Suspected: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Aortic Dissection.

Present Illness History.Output: The patient had a history of hypertension and had had three weeks of intermittent left sided chest pain. The pain radiated to the back. There was no change with exertion. Pains lasted for approximately one minute. She also complained of increasing shortness of breath over the previous month. She became dyspneic performing minimum household chores. She had an occasional nonproductive cough. She had been seen by a GP prior to admission, found to be hypertensive and started on treatment. She complained of night sweats and fever over the previous week but had no weight loss.

Past Medical History.Output: She had previous trauma to the right eye resulting in blindness. She had a total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral oophorectomy in the 1990's.

Medication.Output: Her medications on admission included verapamil 180 mg once per day, ramipril 5 mg once per day, and furosemide 20 mg once per day

Social History.Output: She smoked for ten years, but stopped twenty years ago. She drinks one bottle of beer every six months. She works in the home and lives with her husband.

Auscultate Lungs.Output: The lungs were clear to auscultation and percussion.

Auscultate the Heart.Output: The first and second heart sounds were normal. There was an S4 and a IIVI systolic ejection murmur.

Assess Eyes.Output: Her pupils were equally round and reactive to light. The right cornea was opacified.

Abdomen Examination.Output: The abdomen was soft and nontender with no masses, or organomegaly.

Rectal Examination.Output: NAD and faecal occult blood was negative.

NeckThroat Examination.Output: There was no thyromegaly or adenopathy. Jugular venous pulsations were visible at 8 cm.

Assess Head.Output: Normal.

Neurologic Exam Record.Output: Neurologic exam was normal.

Assess Extremities.Output: No cyanosis or edema.  Radial femoral delay to pulses, unequal.

Urine Dipstick.Output: Trace protein, no blood, 1 nitrites. 3 to 7 WBC's, no RBC's, 10 to 15 squamous epithelial cells, and 3 bacteria.

ECG.Output: Small Q waves in the inferior leads. No ST segment or T wave abnormalities. Voltage within normal limits.

Venous Blood Gas.Output: pH: 7.36 (Normal: 7.33 to 7.44), PCO2: 5.7 (Normal: 5 to 6.4kPa), PO2: 5.9 (Normal: > 5.3 kPa), HCO3: 23 (Normal: 22 to 28 mmolL), Base Excess: 1 (Normal: 2), Saturation: 74 (Normal: 72 to 75%), Lactate: 1.6 (Normal: 0.5 to 2.2 mmolL)

UREA and Electrolytes.Output: Sodium: 142 (Normal: 135 to 145 mmolL), Potassium: 3.9 (Normal: 3.5 to 5.0 mmolL), Urea: 5.5 (Normal: 2.5 to 6.7 mmolL), Creatinine: 102 (Normal: 70 to 150 micromolL), eGFR: 58.5 (Normal: >90mlmin1.73m2)

Clotting Test.Output: Prothrombin Time: 11 (Normal: 10 to 14 seconds), APTT: 23 (Normal: 22 to 36 seconds), Fibrinogen: 2.2 (Normal: 1.5 to 4.5 gL)

FBC.Output: Hb: 87 (Normal: 130 to 180 gL), Hct: 0.28 (Normal: 0.40 to 0.54 LL), MCV: 76 (Normal: 80 to 100 fl), WBC: 8.1 (Normal: 3.6 to 11.0 x 109L), Neut: 7.4 (Normal: 1.8 to 7.5  x 109L), Lymph's: 0.8 (Normal: 1.0 to 4.0  x 109L), Platelet Count: 472 (Normal: 140 to 400 x 109L)

Other Biochemistry Tests.Output: Chloride: 99 (Normal: 95 to 105 mmoll), Glucose: 5.7 (Normal: 3.5 to 5.5 mmolL), Protein Total: 63 (Normal: 60 to 80 gL), Albumin: 31 (Normal: 36 to 50 gL), AST (SGOT): 116 (Normal: 5 to 35 UL), ALP: 168 (Normal: 30 to 150 UL)

trialInfoSet.Prompt: Patient is a 58 year old female presented with shortness of breath.
trialInfoSet.Suspected: Your colleague has been handling the patient with a working hypothesis of Aortic Dissection.

Present Illness History.Output: The patient had a history of hypertension and had had three weeks of intermittent left sided chest pain. The pain radiated to the back. There was no change with exertion. Pains lasted for approximately one minute. She also complained of increasing shortness of breath over the previous month. She became dyspneic performing minimum household chores. She had an occasional nonproductive cough. She had been seen by a GP prior to admission, found to be hypertensive and started on treatment. She complained of night sweats and fever over the previous week but had no weight loss.

Past Medical History.Output: She had previous trauma to the right eye resulting in blindness. She had a total abdominal hysterectomy and bilateral oophorectomy in the 1990's.

Medication.Output: Her medications on admission included verapamil 180 mg once per day, ramipril 5 mg once per day, and furosemide 20 mg once per day

Social History.Output: She smoked for ten years, but stopped twenty years ago. She drinks one bottle of beer every six months. She works in the home and lives with her husband.

Auscultate Lungs.Output: The lungs were clear to auscultation and percussion.

Auscultate the Heart.Output: The first and second heart sounds were normal. There was an S4 and a IIVI systolic ejection murmur.

Assess Eyes.Output: Her pupils were equally round and reactive to light. The right cornea was opacified.

Abdomen Examination.Output: The abdomen was soft and nontender with no masses, or organomegaly.

Rectal Examination.Output: NAD and faecal occult blood was negative.

NeckThroat Examination.Output: There was no thyromegaly or adenopathy. Jugular venous pulsations were visible at 8 cm.

Assess Head.Output: Normal.

Assess Extremities.Output: No cyanosis or edema.  Radial femoral delay to pulses, unequal.

debrief.Hypothesis: How clinicians come to reach their diagnoses
debrief.DiagnosticApproach:
Try to keep a wide differential, using a surgical sieve. 
Base diagnosis on most likely (common things are common) plus what must I not miss.
Try to get most from history, and then use examination and investigations to confirmrefute hypothesis
debrief.Feedback:
I was unsure if it is just the tests which were rationed or also the examination performed? I did not carefully request examination findings and wonder if the clinician is penalised for this. Please could this be clearer?

The section on how confident you are to manage was unclear I thought i always had to tick the 'ready to treat' box and then mid way through realised that this was not the case. 

Perhaps the study is a little long given the complexity of scenarios?
